This is really sad news. He was a very caring person!

In the summer of 1997, I had an internship, and one of my mentors gave me the book "A Fire Upon the Deep". I read it and enjoyed it. Sometime in 1998 or 1999, I had Dr. Vinge as my professor at San Diego State. I didn't realize that he was the author of the book until late in that semester. I stopped by his office to have the book signed, and we talked about science fiction as well as computer science.

I had kept up with him for a few years after graduating, but like everything, life changed and communications eventually dropped.

Rest in peace Dr. Vinge. You'll be missed.

#19

Even the Wikipedia page linked in the article here for A Fire Upon the Deep is a bit dense.

It's classic science fiction, in the sense that it just starts out running and keeps going, without directly explaining things. You wouldn't explain your car's internal combustion engine when talking about driving to an appointment with a client, so why would someone explain their ship's engine technology when talking about traveling through space? Picking up how the world works and understanding it becomes part of the reward of reading; the author sprinkles hints in, without being obvious, and then you get little 'aha!' moments as you progress.

That said, it's not especially tricky in that sense. I doubt strongly that most Ars readers would have much trouble keeping up. Just pay attention to what you're reading, and everything will sort itself out.

A Fire Upon the Deep and A Deepness in the Sky are both transcendent SF novels, space operas that expanded a great deal on the existing genre. Vinge was able to take extremely far-future civilizations and make them seem real in a way that earlier authors didn't. Many of the ideas he came up with have been pulled into mainstream far-future SF, so they're not as mindblowing as they were for contemporary readers, but they're still fantastic, and I recommend them very strongly.

And his Tine race is so interesting.... multiple-bodied minds that communicate via soundwaves, each piece contributing to the greater whole. If the pieces change, so does the mind itself, and "kenning" (choosing good new bodies to add to an existing mind) is a specialization, both art and expertise.

I was just thinking about him a couple months ago, and was checking to see if he'd done anything new. He hadn't, and what a bummer to hear that we'll never get any more. I'll be kind of sad today, I think.

Last edited: Mar 21, 2024

I admit I never read Vinge because of my disdain for Ray Kurzweil and the cult of the singularity. Sounds like I have some catching up to do.

I wouldn't let your reaction to the singularity turn you off from Vinge and his fiction. While he thought the technological singularity solved some problems in our observations and answered some questions, he never seemed to have become a blind believer in the concept. His science fiction very much exists in a universe where superintelligence leads to transcendence for humans (and aliens too), but he clearly approached his tales with the questions "What if?" & "And then what happened?", both of which can lead to good storytelling. And his novels are good storytelling.
